newsitem.title: ARMENIA: SOCCER-INJURY-WEARY VOGTS WANTS WINTER BREAK SCRAPPED.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-INJURY-WEARY VOGTS WANTS WINTER BREAK SCRAPPED.

text.p: German national trainer Berti Vogts, facing a World Cup qualifier in Armenia without seven core players, said on Tuesday that the German league should scrap its two-month winter break.

"Since we've had the winter break we've had injury problems because we force the players to play every three or four days," Vogts told journalists on the eve of Wednesday's match, the first in Germany's campaign.
"The fact is, the players get less and less time to regenerate," he said. "That makes them more vulnerable to injury. We are the only major soccer federation that takes two breaks."
Vogts's predecessor as coach, Bayern Munich president Franz Beckenbauer, supported Vogts.
"We just can't afford to have five months off altogether, and get the the players fit from scratch twice over," he told the sports agency SID, suggesting the break could be cut to just over a month.

Germany's league programme is anyway fairly compact compared to other major European leagues. An 18-team first division means a programme of just 34 league matches, coupled with a much less arduous Cup schedule than in, say, England.
For this reason many of Germany's league clubs have also begun to think the break from mid-December to mid-February, introduced in 1986/87, is counter-productive.
Among the most vociferous are those who have to play in European competitions at a time when the players may not have seen league action for several weeks.
But any shortening of the break would almost certainly prompt protests from less successful league clubs and braodcasters who benefit from traditional winter indoor tournaments.
